div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 45px; margin-left: 113px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Option 1
The dependent class
holds the foreign
key of principal class.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 45px; margin-left: 363px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Option 2
The principal class
holds the foreign key
of dependent class.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 45px; margin-left: 623px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Option 3
The dependent class uses the
principal’s primary key as its
primary key and foreign key.

div.div:
This is the standard
approach for EF Core.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 415px; margin-left: 363px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
This is another option but
cannot handle IsRequired.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 415px; margin-left: 623px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 703px; height: 1px; padding-top: 525px; margin-left: 13px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The three ways of defining a one-to-one relationship in a relational database;
comments at the bottom indicate EF Core’s handling of each approach. Option 1 is different
from options 2 and 3 in that the order of the two ends of the one-to-one relationship are
swapped, which changes which part can be forced to exist. In option 1, the Attendee
must have a Ticket, whereas in options 2 and 3, the Ticket is optional for the
Attendee. Also, if the principal entity (top row) is deleted, the dependent entity
(bottom row) will be deleted too.

switch.text: The three ways of defining a one-to-one relationship in a relational database;...
